data.title: Ireland ‚Äì LONDON CELTIC PUNKS WEB
data.meta_description: Posts about Ireland written by London Celtic Punks, classicalbumreviewer, antomorrayahoocouk, kevingrooney, theold69th, shaneoneill1888, Andy the Celtic Punk Author, and gtmellon
data.text:
A new ‚Äòband‚Äô BT Frankie with their debut 3 track EP of Nord Iron Celtic-Punk! As I said recently their has been a bit of an explosion of Celtic-Punk across Ireland in the last couple of years and while many of the bands for whatever reason would never call themselves Celtic-Punk its undeniable that that‚Ä¶

In our ever ongoing quest to bring you new music we happened upon the soundtrack from the cult movie Good Vibrations. Released back in 2012 it tells of the turbulent life of Belfast DJ, record shop owner, label founder and promoter Terri Hooley from his childhood to the present day. The soundtrack has been put‚Ä¶

We can‚Äôt keep up with everything we receive here all so here‚Äôs a selection of releases that we missed from four completely different bands with differing styles that we love. All the releases are available to stream and download from the Bandcamp app and remember Bandcamp are vultures just like the rest of them but‚Ä¶

Leeson O‚ÄôKeeffe 06/01/1961 ‚Äì 15/04/2024 As many of you will know by now, Leeson O‚ÄôKeefe frontman of the legendary London Celtic Punk band Neck recently died after a short but intense fight with cancer. Leeson was formally diagnosed with Stage 4 pancreatic cancer in January this year but by the time the test results came‚Ä¶

Wow! Quite the coo for Irish Celtic Punkers The Cardinal Sins with 2 singles released in quick succession with very different artists ‚Äì Pi√±ata Protest and Joey Briggs. ‚ÄòDrinking, Fighting, Living, Loving‚Äô with Pi√±ata Protest The second of the two singles was released in April with the amazing Pi√±ata Protest. They are a band that has‚Ä¶

‚ÄúWe are a punk band. We are an Irish folk band. On a good day we are both. On a bad day we are neither‚Äù Mr. Irish Bastard blend the energy of Irish folk with Punk-Rock guitars and attitude. A band that needs little introduction Mr. Irish Bastard came bursting out of the blocks in‚Ä¶

Milan based Celtic-Punk band Andrea Rock And The Rebel Poets release their new four track EP celebrating four incredible women who left their mark on the memory and culture of Ireland. We were introduced to Andrea Rock And The Rebel Poets late into 2024 by a reader, Guida, of the site who thought (quite rightly)‚Ä¶

It‚Äôs over for another year but as our pal Leeson would say ‚Äúeveryday is St. Patrick‚Äôs Day‚Äù so enjoy this bumper collection of diverse as heck Celtic-Punk and Irish Folk tracks that came out over the last couple of weeks from bands from right across the globe. St. Patrick‚Äôs Day is just around the corner so celebrate everything Irish, from reverent to rowdy, on this free download ‚Äúcurated by Amazon‚Äôs Music Experts‚Äù or fair likely picked by AI. 50 songs ‚Äì 3 hours of gaelic classics from sons of Erin like Bing Crosby and Macklemore to friends of Ireland like The Rolling‚Ä¶

The 4 Be 2‚Äôs were a 2nd generation Irish Post-Punk formed in North London in 1979 and who disbanded in 1981. They are the great lost link in the development of Irish music ‚Äì the very first band to ever raise an English born but defiantly Irish voice. The 4‚Ä≥ Be 2‚Ä≥s was Punk band‚Ä¶

Must be hard being the best Irish band in Florida but somehow Clover‚Äôs Revenge put up with it and I‚Äôm sure they have the sympathy of all London Celtic Punks readers! Who better than to pay tribute to one of Tipperary‚Äôs most famous sons than Tipp‚Äôs best Folk band The Rebel Hearts. ‚ÄúTheir hearts in Tipperary wherever they go‚Äù Fitting in the week that Tipperary were over to play London at Gaelic Football in west London (and kinda lucky to escape with a point!) that we‚Ä¶

The new single from Los Angeles based Irish-American Celtic-Punk band Hounds Of Belfast is another original song dedicated to all the fellow hopeless causes out there scraping by and hustling to make ends meet and surely keeps the bar high! After first featuring on these pages last August we have since found it hard to‚Ä¶

Only a handful of albums in the last decade can truly be said to have blown us away and to that list we can add another the new album Italian Celtic-Punk band Andrea Rock And The Rebel Poets. Folk and Punk, tradition and novelty in an album intended for all those who want to understand‚Ä¶

Celtic nations are renowned for their rich cultural heritage all have unique Christmas customs that reflect their history and traditions. Today we explore some of these. Celtic-Punk is also all about tradition so we also pick the seasons best Christmas themed song to showcase. Their was a time it was quite easy to choose which‚Ä¶

Celtic-Punk was invented by the descendants of the Celtic nations while those at home were slow to realise how bloody good is. Eventually though they caught up and here‚Äôs a bunch of releases from across the Celtic nations that we missed first time round. Christmas is just around the corner and London Celtic Punks love‚Ä¶

We might have invented Celtic-Punk here in London but the true home of the genre in 2022 is in North America. Here‚Äôs three diverse albums from this year from across the broad Atlantic that we missed first time round showing the breadth of the scene over there. Christmas is just around the corner and London‚Ä¶

Irish Celtic-Punk band The Outcast Crew recently released a set of professionally recorded live videos recorded on stage in their home town of Portlaoise. To say we‚Äôre fans of the Laois based trad-punk band The Outcast Crew is a bit of a understatement with them featuring heavily in our last two yearly Best Of award shows!‚Ä¶

American Celtic band Runa continue on their new album to breathe fresh life into traditional Celtic music. Digging into the songs and tunes to find the universal thread that binds past to present. I‚Äôm pretty sure that the reason we don‚Äôt get a lot of ‚Äòtrad‚Äô releases for review is that labels, and bands too,‚Ä¶

The second album from St. Doyle & The Last Call Philharmonic with fifteen songs of Trad Irish Folk, Celtic melodies, a Puerto Rican backbeat and a Punk-Rock attitude guaranteed to make you wanna blast it outta your car on the way to the pub! The roots of St. Doyle & The Last Call Philharmonic began‚Ä¶

Beginning a week of posts of pirates and shanties and of those who made their living on the ocean spanning centuries right up to the present day. As a community the London Irish just won‚Äôt lie down. We‚Äôre still here and still fighting you know! We are always delighted to happen upon a new band on the London scene that we can call friends. It was only a couple of months ago that we came across The Poitin‚Äôs. I can‚Äôt remember which‚Ä¶

Acoustic Alternative Folk Rock ‚Äì Made in Bretagne ‚Äì Inspired in Ireland Callum Houston is one of our favourite artists and there‚Äôs not much we look forward to more than some new music from him this time accompanied by Alexandra Matiakh. It‚Äôs generally recognised that their are six Celtic nations. Many though say their are‚Ä¶

It‚Äôs September 17th and you know what that means don‚Äôt you? It‚Äôs exactly half way to St. Patrick‚Äôs Day so in celebration here‚Äôs another in our Classic Album Reviews feature celebrating The Green Hills Of Ireland. Unusually it‚Äôs a fairly recent release but the songs on it actually go further back than we have ever‚Ä¶

Unrelenting, unpredictable and undefeated Black Death Metal with an prominent Irish republican twist. Recorded during Fall 2022 and Winter 2023 in Pennsylvania and Derry. There is very little information out there on the Bogside Sniper Squadron except that they are a completely new band that includes members from USA and Ireland and that someone let‚Ä¶

The Celtic-Punk scene continues to throw up interesting and innovative bands with Californian Irish-Americans the Hounds Of Belfast one of the latest to grace these pages. They have a fantastic new single out and lots more original music to soon follow! As life moves on so does social media. Being a somewhat aging Luddite (Celtic)‚Ä¶

With a new album due out on Saturday and a London Celtic Punks gig with American band Brave The Sea on Friday there‚Äôs no better time to get our auld mate Anto to fill out the Celtic-Punk Q And A. Filled to the brim with Anto-isms get along to The Birds Nest on Friday and‚Ä¶

This week sees the fifty-third anniversary of the tragically young death of Irish ballad and country singer and recording artist Willie Brady. Popular in Ireland and abroad in the 1950‚Äôs and 1960‚Äôs he was singing and recording ballads long before the ‚ÄòBallad Boom‚Äô arrived in Ireland and recorded over twenty albums before he very sadly‚Ä¶

Well Kevin Rooney had that pleasure at the Irish Rover in New York and here takes us back twenty years to that night! On the 12th‚Ä¶

Many, many moons ago (nine in fact) we published‚Ä¶

The World‚Äôs Loudest Folk Band One of the first and most enduring bands on the Celtic-Punk underground, Chicago‚Äôs The Tossers are back with a ‚Äònew‚Äô album of classics, standards and originals that mix the attitude and swagger of Punk Rock with a muscular but respectful approximation of Irish traditional Folk music. Four great bands in one night celebrating the Pogues, the godfather and forebears of everything celtic punk. What could possibly be bad? Not a lot, I‚Äôll sure as hell say. Same Again Tomorrow is the new full length album from Kilmaine Saints. Featuring thirteen songs of high energy Celtic Rock and Punk, this album is a statement from a band taking their sound to the next level. It‚Äôs been an incredible six years since The Kilmaine Saints released their last studio album Whiskey Blues & Faded‚Ä¶

Drawing from the ashes of their ancestors and modern music alike, Los Angeles based Green Ashes new EP Cannery Row is original Folk-Rock music for fighters and lovers. We only recently found out about Green Ashes when we featured them as our ‚ÄòBlast From The Past‚Äô on last months Odds‚Äôn‚ÄôSods ‚Äì Celtic Punk Round Up.‚Ä¶

Mighty McGuiggans Fort Wayne, Indiana combine lively Irish fun with original compositions and some well trod covers. Gritty, real and beautiful, like a single malt scotch or a fine stout. Raucous drinking songs, beautiful ballads, hilarious songs that tell a story and some pirate tunes to boot! We were delighted to hear from American Irish‚Ä¶

With so much new Celtic-Punk to review we very very rarely go back in time for releases we missed the first time round but we are making an exception today for Costa Mesa, Californian Celtic-Punk band The Provos debut album. FROM THE PLOUGH TO THE STARS A free collection of over twenty Irish rebel songs from some of the Celtic-Punk scenes best bands. Ancient, modern and contemporary. The tradition goes on. Just in time for the beginning of the most important month in Celtic culture we‚Äôre delighted to bring you this new compilation. Twenty-one bands‚Ä¶

New single from Graveyard Johnnys guitarist Callum Houston. Acoustic Alternative Folk Rock ‚Äì Made in Bretagne ‚Äì Inspired in Ireland. Carrigaline, county Cork native Callum Houston can usually be found singing songwriting around his home near Lorient in Brittany in the local pubs and clubs. When he‚Äôs not doing that he plays guitar in Premier‚Ä¶

The second album from The Scuntz a ever changing collective of alcoholic hillbilly punks from Belfast. Thriving in despair, they patiently await the rapture, charged with entertaining the unwashed masses left behind. Sneaking out just a couple of days before Christmas was the second album from Belfast Punx The Scuntz. Not giving us much time‚Ä¶

Four great album releases including three bands who released their debuts in 2022 and one celebrating their 10th anniversary all get the London Celtic Punks treatment. Ranging from Celtic-Punk to Irish-Folk to Punk these are the bands that make our nights out special. Hoping you all had a great Christmas and are looking forward to‚Ä¶

Probably the most prolific of Celtic-Punk bands whether it comes to recording and releasing new material or indeed playing in your local neighbourhood it‚Äôs the welcome return of‚Ä¶

In a months time two of Ireland‚Äôs most interesting bands go head to head on the same night in north London. Aye some eejit has booked them both to play 15th December in Camden only a few hundred yards apart. We are caught in a dilemma of which one to go to ourselves so here‚Ä¶

What a year this is going to be for all you Celtic-Punk aficionados out there with the two major players in the scene both releasing new albums within just a few weeks of each other. Later in the month sees the Dropkick Murphys but today our man back on the auld sod Shane O‚ÄôNeill runs‚Ä¶

Mychal Judge, was an American Franciscan friar and Catholic priest who served as a chaplain to the FDNY. While serving in that capacity he was killed, becoming the first certified fatality of the September 11, 2001 attacks. Irish-American Father Mychal Fallon Judge O.F.M. was the first official certified fatality of the nearly 3,000 people that‚Ä¶

The Dead Irish formed during the pandemic in Dublin and describe themselves as Irish trad/punk band based in Dublin. Their brilliant debut single just came out and is four songs of original proper Irish styled Celtic-Punk. The most surprising development in Celtic-Punk since the end of the Covid lockdowns seems to have been that the‚Ä¶

Trad Punk from the depths of Dublin city! Lost In The City is the first release from Irish trad punk band The Dead Irish. Led by Barney Murray of Blood Or Whiskey fame the song is fuelled by classic Irish folk influences. Just the other day we received a track in the mail from The Winter‚Ä¶

The Scratch come from Dublin and have become the latest sensation on the Irish music scene with their loud and catchy as hell acoustic owing much to alternative forms of music as the auld Irish Folk legends. As usual it‚Äôs been impossible to keep up with the flow of new music over the St. Patrick‚Äôs day period. It seems like ages since St. Patrick‚Äôs Day and well it kind of is. It was early March 2019 when the Covid lockdowns began and that years St. Patrick‚Äôs festivities were among the first to fall. So fast forward two years and here we are again except this time with plenty to be grateful for. ‚Ä¶

With impeccable timing the new single from Sir Reg just beat the Irish government to ‚ÄòOpen The Pubs‚Äô. A sentiment we can all agree with! In a world of uncertainty, there‚Äôs few things that will lift your spirits like a raucous, rollicking slice of Celtic-Folk-Punk, and Swedish/Irish band Sir Reg are happy to oblige! Formed‚Ä¶

Here‚Äôs hoping you all had a great Christmas and New Year. Despite everything it‚Äôs been another great year for music. Maybe not quite as much of it but things are picking up and the end of 2021 saw us caught in a deluge of music we couldn‚Äôt keep up with. Any regular reader will know‚Ä¶

The debut album from Ireland‚Äôs newest Celtic-Punk band- The Outcast Crew. Ten original roaring trad punk songs about myths, folklore and singalong sea shanties! Strangely there aren‚Äôt a huge amount of Celtic Punk bands based in Ireland, so we were delighted to receive the debut album Myths & Yarns from The Outcast Crew. It is‚Ä¶

Texas Celtic-Punk band Blaggards (there is no ‚Äòthe‚Äô) play what they call Stout Irish Rock. Traditional Irish mixed with Rock‚Äôn‚ÄôRoll, informed by everything from Johnny Cash and Elvis to Thin Lizzy and Sabbath. Their new album has just hit the shops Unbelievably this is the fourth Celtic-Punk album out of Texas in just the last‚Ä¶

After 30 years of leading renowned Celtic-Punk rockers, The Mahones, Finny McConnell decided that it was time to make an album for himself. Showcasing his intimate songwriting skills, Finny also includes covers of songs with deep meaning to him. The Dark Streets of Love is a collection of his most intimate music, stripped bare. Earlier‚Ä¶

The Pogues. The Mahones. Flogging Molly. The Dropkicks. All bands who‚Äôve made their mark on the Celtic-Punk genre. But we can‚Äôt forget the lesser-known bands too, the musicians working tirelessly to keep the flag up and flyin‚Äô! In his first guest post, Andy Beck (aka. The Celtic Punk Author) showcases the old and new from‚Ä¶

In 1975 The Miami Showband were riding high in the Irish music scene, known as The Irish Beatles and credited with being Ireland‚Äôs #1 band. The showband scene had enjoyed huge popularity from the late 1950‚Äôs, through the 60‚Äôs and on into 70‚Äôs‚Ä¶ until one fateful night in July 1975. Here we discuss the background‚Ä¶

From the scene. For the scene. After months of planning, organising and fund-raising the compilation album Raise Your Pints #6 has finally been delivered. Twenty bands from eleven countries celebrating (might be the wrong word- editor) the virus lockdowns in Celtic-Folk-Punk style. Anyone remember the original Celtic-Punk samplers from Shite‚Äôn‚ÄôOnions? I think they stretched to‚Ä¶

First new solo music in four years from Travis O‚ÄôNeill Sligo born resident of Prague and vocalist for legendary Czech Celtic-Punk band great Pipes And Pints. An ode to his days in North London! Camden and North London at the time I lived there was a real stronghold of the Irish and the London Irish‚Ä¶

Shamrocks, leprechauns and gallons and gallons of Guinness must mean it‚Äôs almost St. Patrick‚Äôs Day. But who was St. Patrick and why has this Saint‚Äôs day become so popular? Influenced by local hero Springsteen and countless other country troubadours, Sean Tobin grew up in the New Jersey bar scene and owes his high-energy performances to his time spent busking on the streets of Galway. With a handful of releases behind him his excellent new EP celebrates his Irish roots and St. Patrick‚Äôs Day. Born and‚Ä¶

Four second-generation Irish lads, three brothers and their best friend from school write songs about identity and belonging. With influences as diverse as Brendan Shine, The Pogues and The Stone Roses their mission is to get people dancing and thinking. Hot on the heels of their last single, the fantastic, ‚ÄòGod Bless You And Keep You‚Äô,‚Ä¶

Our regular monthly feature of all the Celtic-Punk news that‚Äôs fit to print. Band news, record releases, videos, tours (not individual gigs though yet sadly), live streams, crowd funders etc., send it into us at londoncelticpunks@hotmail.co.uk or through the Contact Us page. All will get a mention but I need YOU to help if it‚Äôs‚Ä¶

Well here we go again. It seems an awful long time since we were compiling all the votes into 2019‚Äôs Best Of. Last year saw The Walker Roaders triumph but with this year being a lot quieter on the Celtic-Punk front thanks to the lockdowns around the world bands have found themselves unable to tour‚Ä¶

2020 was by and large a shitty year for music. Sure their were a few bright spots‚Ä¶ off the top of my head the many Live Streams but it was never going to replace live gigs for the Celtic-Punk scene where live gigs are everything. Even in a year with much fewer releases we still‚Ä¶

Each December we pick the best Christmas themed song we‚Äôve heard that year to showcase in our end of year message. Their was a time when it was a easy choice but over the years its become quite common, so much so that we will have a special feature on 2020‚Äôs Celtic-Punk Christmas songs on‚Ä¶

The first ‚Äònew‚Äô release from The Pogues for quite a while compiles all their various BBC Sessions between April 1984 and July 1985. This CD/ digital release includes two sessions not included on the recent vinyl version of this album. The Pogues ‚Äì BBC Sessions is the definitive complete collection that The Pogues recorded for‚Ä¶

Our short series on the songs of Andy Nolan continues today with another five of Andy‚Äôs masterpieces. As a past member of Shane MacGowan And The Popes and Spider Stacy‚Äôs Vendettas he has a great musical legacy but it‚Äôs as accordion player and songwriter for London Irish musical tour-de-force The Bible Code Sundays that Andy‚Äôs‚Ä¶

Andy Nolan is best known on these pages as the accordion player and songwriter for the London Irish musical tour-de-force The Bible Code Sundays and as an ex-member of Shane MacGowan And The Popes and Spider Stacy‚Äôs Vendettas but there‚Äôs a lot more to him than just being an expert accordionist. It‚Äôs thirty-eight years to the day that The Pogues, then known as Pogue Mahone first trod the boards at their debut gig at The Pindar of Wakefield in Kings Cross, London. At their height, The Pogues were as vivid an embodiment of the Irish of London as you‚Äôre ever likely to see. Their songs bled‚Ä¶

The next in our series of ‚ÄòClassic Album Reviews‚Äô this time features Scottish Folk-Rock group The Humblebums. Phil Kelly is the young anti-hero of Clash Of the Ash. A restless teenager, a fan of The Cramps and The Pogues, great at Hurling but with a strong aversion to studying. Pressured by those around him ‚Äì from his Mum to do well at his exams, his Dad to take a job at the local‚Ä¶

If you want to indulge in Celtic Folk Rock, you will definitely take pleasure in Paddy Murphy. Homesickness, the struggle for freedom, sailor‚Äôs yarns, love of the odd drink and the rebellious Irish spirit coming together in a musical whirlwind from Austria! Ryan and McGrath polish up their Guns, As we sit and wait for the English Huns The hills alive with Summer a beauty to be seen, * Washed and fed by the Dunnes Prayed‚Ä¶

Six bands, three from Ireland and three London based. No longer able to play their trade due to government lockdowns either side of the Irish Sea have been virtually brought together by one man ‚Äì Phil Parsons and one pub ‚Äì Frostys Bar, Kenton to create a lockdown album like no other. Anti Depressants are a four piece Ska, Punk‚Äôn‚ÄôRoll band from the hills of County Armagh. Going since 2008 they already have four albums behind them but the last one was in 2013. One of the biggest bands of their generation and fronted by a real larger than life character the first album from legendary Dublin band The Boomtown Rats in thirty-six years is finally out. Gerry Mellon gives us the rundown on the Rats sixth album. Before I start, I must tell you that when Bob and‚Ä¶

The Mahones have always been one of Celtic-Punk‚Äôs heavyweights and last month celebrated their 30th anniversary in style with another knockout album to add to their ‚ÄòIrish Punk Collection‚Äô! The Mahones are well regarded amongst Celtic-Punk fans and recognised indeed as pioneers of the scene. Formed in 1990 on St. Patrick‚Äôs Day in Kingston, Ontario‚Ä¶
